title: And theyre off : Suella Braverman fires the starting gun – POLITICO
body_text:
Good Tuesday morning. This is Rosa Prince with Andrew McDonald at Liberal Democrat conference in Bournemouth.
DRIVING THE DAY
TORY CONTEST KICKS OFF: Home Secretary Suella Braverman will fire the starting gun on the next Conservative leadership contest with a barnstorming speech Stateside calling on world leaders to rip up the 70-year-old U.N. Refugee Convention and introduce a migration regime “fit for our modern age.” It’s the stuff of grassroot Tory fantasies, a bold declaration that: “Seeking asylum and seeking better economic prospects are not the same thing.” She’s even brought a TV crew along for the ride.
Living her best life: Braverman wakes this morning in the splendid surroundings of the British ambassador’s mansion in Washington — Playbook was there recently and can confirm it’s pretty fab. As she sips a glass of Tropicana and flicks through the press cuttings, it’s easy to imagine the trace of a smile playing on her lips. The home sec’s bold words splash the Mail, Express and Telegraph, which carries a striking full-length portrait of her. Take that, Kemi!
American pie: The centerpiece of Braverman’s three-day U.S. trip is her speech this afternoon at the American Enterprise Institute, from 3.30 p.m. It marks the first time Braverman has directly taken aim at the 1951 Refugee Convention, although her views on its European counterpart, the ECHR, are well known.
**A message from Google: Every year Google helps people across the UK collectively make an extra £7 billion from their side projects, using tools like Gmail and YouTube. Read more in our Economic Impact Report 2023.**
Tearing up the rules: In her speech, Braverman says refugees cannot be allowed to “shop around” for safe havens, arguing that the convention is being interpreted as providing a right to asylum to those who face discrimination, rather than the higher bar of persecution. She’ll argue this means as many as 780 million people could in theory be eligible for resettlement.
In numbers: The Telegraph says the 780 million figure is made up of an estimate of the numbers who could have a “well-founded fear of being persecuted” on the grounds of race, religion and nationality, added to 89 million forcibly displaced, and 40 million in modern slavery. Braverman will go on to say that “Nobody entering the U.K. by boat from France is fleeing imminent peril,” adding: “There is an argument that they should cease to be treated as refugees when considering the legitimacy of their onward movement.”
Didn’t get the memo: The reaction from refugee charities is, as might be expected, unenthusiastic. Writing in the, checks notes, Express, Enver Solomon of the Refugee Council says tearing up the Refugee Convention would diminish Britain’s proud postwar record of coming to the aid of those in need. Shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper adds: “The Home Secretary has given up on fixing the Tories’ asylum chaos at home so now she’s resorting to grandstanding abroad and looking for anyone else to blame.”
Never mind the haters: Braverman won’t care about the pushback from charities and NGOs — but that broader question of whether her rhetoric will be accompanied by success in actually stopping the boats, one of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s all-important five pledges, becomes ever more pertinent as we hurtle toward the election.
What Suella did next: Braverman will later meet members of U.S. President Joe Biden’s administration, including Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas and Attorney General Merrick Garland, for talks on migration and national security. Following her call for social media firms to do more to tackle online child abuse, the home secretary will also visit the U.S. National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. And she’ll see work to tackle America’s epidemic of opioid abuse.
EVERYONE’S A CRITIC: Separately, Braverman was criticized by former Director of Public Prosecutions Ken McDonald over her tweet at the weekend in support of armed Met Police cops who handed in their guns and badges in protest at the prosecution of a colleague accused of murdering Chris Kaba. “I think her intervention was a little unwise, frankly,” given her constitutional position, he told Times Radio.
ALSO IN THE STATES: A newly signed memorandum of understanding (MoU) will allow British aerospace and aviation firms to more easily send engineers to the U.S. state of Washington, Business and Trade Minister Nus Ghani told POLITICO. The U.K. announced the new MoU deal Monday night — the sixth deal with a U.S. state since the start of 2022.
Washington on your side: The Department for Business and Trade said the deal would ensure “investor intros, trade missions, and increasing access to procurement markets” for the aerospace industry. Seattle, Washington’s largest city, is a major hub for aerospace companies such as Boeing and SpaceX. Other “priority areas” include “clean energy, digital, life sciences, supply chain resilience, agriculture, and innovation.”
Who’s next? Ghani said the next MoU will likely be with the state of Florida — the home of Republican presidential candidate Ron DeSantis. The Florida governor met Business and Trade Secretary Kemi Badenoch earlier this year during a trip to London.
END OF THE LINE
TRAIN DELAYS — TILL NOVEMBER: What remains of Westminster is still obsessing over the greatest will-they-won’t-they since Rachel dithered over whether to get on the plane to Paris or stay with Ross: the future of HS2. After days of speculation, the Times seems to have been given a full briefing, concluding the project will indeed be scaled back — but with a formal announcement delayed until the Autumn Statement in November.
Huh? What’s the point in that? It’s hard to make much sense of a Downing Street comms strategy which set a hare running that the Manchester branch of the project would be axed this week, only to stay the execution in the face of a tsunami of criticism. The opposition now numbers — count ’em — two former prime ministers, three ex-chancellors, three current mayors, a former transport secretary or two and, according to the FT, NFL star Tom Brady.
But but but: Given how many years these arguments have been playing out, surely No. 10 would have been braced for the backlash.
And why were senior Cabinet ministers — Grant Shapps and Jeremy Hunt — allowed to show ankle in recent days by all but confirming that HS2 was on the chopping block? Especially given that the entire Cabinet was about to decamp for party conference in, where else, Manchester.
Could it be … cock-up rather than conspiracy? The first sniff of a hint that HS2 was in peril came a fortnight ago, when intrepid Downing Street photographer Steve Back, who tweets as @PoliticalPics, spotted what appeared to be a document relating to the spiraling costs of the project. The story was stood up by the Independent last week, and once out there, ministers such as Shapps and Hunt who faced questions were in a pickle; to their credit neither denied a story they presumably knew by then to be true.
Still speculation here: No. 10 then had the choice whether to, as with the net-zero retreat on Wednesday, bring forward the announcement that parts of HS2 were due to be iced. After agonizing for a couple of days, it seems a decision has been taken that doing so now, on the eve of a Manchester conference, would be just too toxic.
And so: Making the best of a bad job, the government spin machine has now been let loose, with briefings that Rishi Sunak had become “alarmed” at the spiraling costs and profligacy of the project. The Times says HS2 executives acted like “kids with the golden credit card.” The Mail reports that ministers have known for a couple of years that the business case for HS2 “doesn’t stack up.”
All aboard the gravy train: The PM was concerned that there were more than 40 HS2 Ltd. executives paid more than £150,000, with outgoing Chief Executive Mark Thurston trousering £640,000 a year, the Times suggests.
Sweetening the pill: The Guardian reports that Sunak and Hunt will seek to sweeten the pill for Manchester and points further north by reallocating money saved from scrapping the upper reaches of HS2 (and stranding London-bound passengers at Old Oak Common) in other transport projects. This could include Northern Powerhouse Rail between Manchester and Leeds and even a new underground rail station in Manchester, the Times says.
Sneaky move: After the Independent suggested that rather than scrapping the Manchester line altogether Hunt could announce a delay of seven years, the Times points out this would help balance the books by pushing the cost into a new financial period for the purposes of assessment by the Office for Budget Responsibility.
See you in 2 months’ time: For more of the same briefing and counter briefing when we do it all over again at the Autumn Statement.
GOOD NEWS FOR RISHI: Last week’s net-zero reset has reaped rewards at the polls, if not for the planet. A new poll by Deltapoll shows the Labour lead has shrunk by 8 points, with the PM’s decision to delay the ban on new petrol and diesel cars proving something of a winner. The Sun has more.
ALL ABOUT THE EVS: Meanwhile, British trade officials will meet with their EU counterparts Wednesday to discuss post-Brexit tariffs on electric cars, Bloomberg reports. As POLITICO told you earlier this month, a major split has opened up in Brussels over the issue, raising hopes in London that new tariffs could be scrapped.
RISHI’S RESET: YouGov has done some snap polling on the other measures Sunak is said to be mulling as part of his government reset. The proposal to ban youngsters from buying cigarettes seems the most popular, with 71 percent in favor. Asked for their experience of inheritance tax (which Sunak and Hunt are reported to be mooting axing, only 4 percent said they had paid tax on an inheritance, 23 percent had inherited money without paying tax and 65 percent had never received an inheritance.
This might be a goer, Steve: Two-thirds of those polled supported (either strongly or somewhat) fining those who failed to turn up for NHS appointments.
WATCH YOUR RIGHT FLANK: The New Conservative group of 2017 and 2019 MPs will hold a rally at Tory conference demanding Sunak introduce policies including withdrawal from the ECHR, protecting female-only safe spaces and bringing in tax cuts, the Express’ David Maddox reports.
LIBERAL DEMOCRAT LAND
DAVEY DAY … PART II: Lib Dem leader Ed Davey will close his party’s first fall conference in four years with an election rallying call, Andrew McDonald writes — as the Lib Dems coalesce around a blue wall-focused strategy. His speech is at 2.30 p.m.
Some of those lines: According to pre-released extracts, he’ll argue that “voting Conservative is bad for your health.” The speech will have a healthy dose of focus on … health, as well as the cost of living and how best to get the Tories out. He’ll say: “Britain isn’t working, because the Conservatives aren’t working. They’re more like a bad TV soap opera than a functioning government.”
Also in there: Davey will talk about his personal experience as a carer in some depth — and a new Lib Dem health policy, to be announced in the speech, is also expected.
What won’t be in there: Any big calls for Britain to rejoin the EU or much chat about Europe at all. Davey will devote a chunk of the speech to a Europe strategy, but don’t expect anything new. Instead of banging on about Brexit, the Lib Dems are pursuing an ultra-focused strategy aimed at winning a number (more on that in a minute) of seats in the blue wall. Andrew has a big piece on the Lib Dem’s plans here.
That’s numberwang: Lib Dem officials have been hesitant to put a number on the party’s aims for the next election, for obvious reasons. Playbook has heard a few numbers tossed about by activists — one said they hoped the party could win 35 to 40 seats, a fair few reckoned doubling would be a great result and another said they dreamed of usurping the SNP as the third-largest party. That would require at least 30 seats, in all likelihood.
ICYMI: The Lib Dem leadership lost out in a bid to scrap its own national housebuilding target. Andrew had more in Monday’s Playbook PM.
LAST NIGHT AT GLEE CLUB: Activists old and young gathered in a tightly packed (once again, more below) space at the Marriott for Glee Club — the Lib Dems’ big moment to let their hair down and sing strangely remixed ditties about liberalism.
As usual: Ears were ringing with songs from the 1900s about Lloyd George, even older laments referencing land reform, and a rather smutty number devoted to Mark Oaten’s unsuccessful 2006 leadership bid (torpedoed after the News of the World revealed he hired a sex worker and … let’s just leave it there). Plus guests were treated to a rousing sing-along of Flower of Scotland led by Scottish MPs and Scottish leader Alex Cole-Hamilton. One Lib Dem attendee said it was like a third divorcee’s wedding get-together.
This is democracy manifest: This year’s Glee Club was so popular that a 40-minute queue formed outside, forcing hotel staff to implement a one-in-one-out policy. So far, so good. But as the venue’s toilets were outside, revelers who wanted to relieve themselves had to effectively kick themselves out. Which is less than ideal for any journalists attending for work purposes … or activists consuming a lot of alcohol. Or both.

TODAY IN WESTMINSTER
PARLIAMENT: In recess.
LABOUR LAND: Labour would publish guidance for small employers on measures to support women experiencing menopause at work, Shadow Women and Equalities Secretary Anneliese Dodds will announce at the Women in Work Summit — she’s is on the morning round.
What else Labour wants to talk about: New Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Liz Kendall will today accuse the government of allowing the U.K. to become the only OECD country to decline in terms of employment, unemployment and inactivity since the pandemic. A Tory spokesperson sneered in response: “Labour have never left office with unemployment lower than when they came into power.”
School of hard knocks: The i splashes on Labour introducing VAT on private school fees immediately if it wins power — Poppy Wood has the scoop.
SOUTH KOREA STATE VISIT: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol will pay a state visit to Britain in November, after accepting an invitation from King Charles, Reuters reports. Buckingham Palace will host Yoon and his wife, Kim Keon Hee, with more details about the visit to be released at a later date.
THE KIDS ARE ALRIGHT: Tens of thousands of 16-to-24-year-olds will have access to additional support in finding work as the DWP’s Youth Offer expands.
BEHIND BARS: One in 10 prisons in England and Wales are barely fit for purpose and should be shut down if alternative buildings can be found, HM Chief Inspector of Prisons Charlie Taylor told the Guardian, which makes their splash — Rajeev Syal has the exclusive.
YIKES: Artificial intelligence may allow terrorists to develop dangerous bioweapons and cripple infrastructure with cyberattacks as its creators do not understand how it works, DSIT Secretary Michelle Donelan warned — the i’s Hugo Gye has more. Writing for the paper, Donelan said the government’s forthcoming AI summit would look at preventing both misuse by bad actors and losing control of the technology.
REDWOOD’S TAKE: The Bank of England has cost taxpayers £24 billion to cover losses from selling bonds to April 2023, a figure which could rise to £100 billion, an Institute of Economic Affairs report by Tory MP John Redwood says.
LEFT BEHIND: The poorest third of families will see almost no direct benefit from the government’s expansion of free childcare as the reforms prioritize working parents, an IFS report finds.
DAY IN COURT: Five Bulgarian nationals accused of spying for Russia for almost three years appear at Westminster Magistrates’ Court — via Reuters.
SW1 EVENTS: Daily Telegraph Pol Ed Ben Riley-Smith launches his forthcoming book The Right to Rule: Thirteen Years, Five Prime Ministers and the Implosion of the Tories on Victoria Embankment from 6.30 p.m. (Invite only.)

BEYOND THE M25
IN POLAND: The Home Office will today announce funding for the War Crimes Documentation Center in Poland to expand international efforts to collect evidence of Russian atrocities in Ukraine.
ARMENIA UPDATE: Nagorno-Karabakh Armenians are facing up to a life in exile, as thousands seek to leave after Azerbaijan launched a lightning attack into the ethnic Armenian territory. People are running away in increasing numbers, fearing ethnic cleansing at the hands of the Azerbaijani military, POLITICO’s Gabriel Gavin reports.
ACROSS THE POND: Northern Ireland Minister Jonathan Caine, Irish Minister Darragh O’Brien and U.S. Special Envoy for Northern Ireland Joe Kennedy III are among those marking 25 years of the Good Friday Agreement at the Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston, Massachusetts from 2 p.m. … Sinn Féin MP John Finucane and SDLP leader Colum Eastwood also speak on a later panel.
GOING NOWHERE: U.S. New Jersey Senator Bob Menendez said he would not resign after accusations of using his office to benefit New Jersey businesspeople and the Egyptian government in exchange for gold bars, cash and a luxury vehicle. He said he would be “exonerated” when all the facts are presented — via my Stateside colleagues.

Deputy leader of the Lib Dems Daisy Cooper broadcast round: Today program (6.50 a.m.) … GB News (7.40 a.m.) … Times Radio (7.50 a.m.) … BBC Radio Wales (8.15 a.m.) … LBC News (8.50 a.m.).

Politics Live (BBC Two 12.15 p.m.): Leveling-Up Minister Lee Rowley … Shadow Employment Minister Alison McGovern … the New Statesman’s Rachel Cunliffe … the Telegraph’s Ben Riley-Smith.
TODAY’S FRONT PAGES
POLITICO UK: Britain’s anti-Brexit Lib Dems are back … But don’t mention the EU.
Daily Express: Suella urges reform of “absurd” migrant system.
Daily Mail: Suella — Channel migrants are not refugees.
Daily Mirror: Brand — sex assault claims grow.
Daily Star: Rampant rabbits.
Financial Times: Scrapping HS2 will hurt trust in U.K., warn Birmingham City’s U.S. owners.
i: Labour to hit private schools with 20 percent VAT in first year of winning power.
Metro: Brand — police probe more sex claims.
The Daily Telegraph: Braverman — 780 million “refugees” shows rules must change.
The Guardian: Shocking state of prisons means “one in 10 should be closed down.”
The Independent: Cabinet split over Sunak’s HS2 “gross act of vandalism.”
The Sun: Cops probe Brand “sex assaults.”
The Times: PM alarmed by runaway cost of HS2.
LONDON CALLING
WESTMINSTER WEATHER: Light rain and a moderate breeze. Highs of 23C.
SPOTTED … at Lib Dem Glee Club: Former leader Jo Swinson … MPs Layla Moran and Wendy Chamberlain … Scottish Lib Dem leader Alex Cole-Hamilton … Lib Dem London mayoral candidate Rob Blackie … Spinners Paul Haydon, Sam Fisk and Ami Wyllie … Lobby hacks Pippa Crerar, Tom Harwood, Freddie Hayward, George Parker, Dominic Penna, Genevieve Holl-Allen and Stephen Bush … and former MP Simon Hughes.
Also spotted … at the official Liberal Democrat candidates’ reception hosted by iNHouse: Lib Dem leader Ed Davey … Deputy leader Daisy Cooper … MPs Sarah Dyke, Wendy Chamberlain, Layla Moran and Christine Jardine … English Candidates Committee Chair Margaret Joachim … candidates including Josh Babarinde (Eastbourne), Andrew George (St Ives), Shaffaq Mohammed (Sheffield Hallam), Tessa Munt (Wells), Lisa Smart (Hazel Grove) and Max Wilkinson (Cheltenham) … former leader Jo Swinson … and inHouse’s Hanna Johnson, Jamie Ali, Nick Raikes and Katie Perrior.
Also spotted … at the U.K. launch of the Taskforce for Nature-related Financial Disclosures, hosted by the Green Finance Institute: Environment Secretary Thérèse Coffey … Permanent Secretary for the Treasury Joanna Penn … World Wide Fund for Nature Chief Executive Tanya Steele … SpAd James Cullimore … Bloomberg’s Katherine Griffiths … and the New Statesman’s Megan Kenyon.
MATCH REPORT: Fresh from their victory against the Lobby XI, the Brunswick Group took a 1-0 victory over Labour in a football game in west London. Director Ruan Tremayne scored the winning goal and, despite a tireless performance from Labour, the party couldn’t equalize. Brunswick is now set on taking on the Tories.
NEW GIG: Tory peer and former Downing Street Deputy Chief of Staff Ben Gascoigne becomes patron of the Conservative Animal Welfare Foundation.
CONGRATS TO: Ollie Cole is now Times Radio’s political producer.
JOB AD: The House of Commons is hiring a committee reporter.
YOU’VE GOT MAIL: The Treasury has allowed the public to submit policy ideas for the forthcoming Autumn Statement until 5 p.m. on October 13.
IN THE BOOKSHOPS: The Identity Trap: A Story of Ideas and Power in Our Time by the Atlantic’s Yascha Mounk, exploring the origins of identity politics, is published by Allen Lane … and The Fall: The End of the Murdoch Empire by journalist Michael Wolff is published by the Bridge Street Press.
FLASH GORDON: Former Prime Minister Gordon Brown speaks at a Guardian Live event about his forthcoming book Permacrisis: A Plan To Fix A Fractured World, in conversation with Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland, at Cadogan Hall from 7 p.m.
DON’T MISS: The wait is finally over — former Health Secretary Matt Hancock’s £45,000 appearance on Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins kicks off at 9.30 p.m. on Channel 4. One preview clip showed Hancock being punched in the face by former footballer Jermaine Pennant — gulp!
NOAH’S CULTURE FIX: Former Downing Street adviser and author of Whips Cleo Watson examines the dark arts of political campaigning in a three-part Radio 4 series titled How to Win a Campaign. The contributor list includes a stellar cast of Dominic Cummings, Fiona Hill, James Schneider and former Keir Starmer adviser Chris Ward. The first episode — Building a Strategy — is at 9.30 a.m.
NOW READ: In the i, political scientist John Curtice examines how Rishi Sunak’s polling has been affected by his announcement on net-zero policies, saying many voters viewed his statement “through a partisan lens.”
